byline.contributor: Manny Fernandez reported from Houston, and Richard Pérez-Peña from New York.
byline.original: By MANNY FERNANDEZ and RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

abstract: Texas is confronted with challenging task of fixing its voter identification law following federal appears court ruling that law discriminates against minorities; ruling keeps law in place but requires alterations aimed at minimizing it’s effect on those who do not have government-issued photo identification card, many of whom are black or Hispanic.
lead_paragraph: A judge must create procedures to soften the effects of the restrictions before the November election after an appeals court ruled that the law discriminated against minorities.

headline.main: In Texas, Fixing Voter ID Law Ruled to Be Discriminatory Will Be Tricky Task
headline.print_headline: Fixing Voter ID Law Ruled to Be Discriminatory Will Be Tricky Task for Texas
